Does anyone know anything about the barriers to setting up telescopes for remote observation? I'm absolutely not an expert. https://t.co/2yTo9ZZjMx

@zeikonline Absolutely. When I was at the INT it struck me just how massively inaccessible it was. Several flights of stairs, a narrow control room, a lift you can't use during the night... it was built in the 60s-80s and it shows.
@zeikonline Yeah, it can be difficult to have to rely on someone else's competence! And the quality of the observations will depend on the astronomer who takes them...
@zeikonline Can retweet your question if you like, I am certain some of my followers know much more than me!

@zeikonline And the Gemini telescopes have sea-level control rooms, I think. But most telescopes (especially older ones) are very inaccessible and I do suspect they also severely lack funding to make them any other way.

@zeikonline Quite often observations are done in service mode, where an on-site astronomer takes them for you. You have less control, although some telescopes do a thing where you can watch the images come in as they're taken and contact the astronomer if they're doing it wrong.

@zeikonline I'm genuinely not an expert, but I would guess that the issue is partially funding, partially the need for an extremely reliable internet connection and partially just that it's much easier to monitor and react to weather and astronomical conditions if you're actually there.
@Astro__Rick Yes! It's so good as a combo and I don't know anyone else who eats them!

I've seen tweets judging academics for still working. I just started my first postdoc. I am already going to struggle to maintain my career in astronomy as a disabled person. I thought precarity was one of the things folk were striking over.

I don't usually make a big deal of this but I want to make it clear that I completely support the Four Fights ongoing strike action and although I can't strike myself without doing actual damage to my career I have donated to the strike fund.

@Jesstella Desktop! I don't use half the features though. Mostly use it to make sure the weird hours I work average out to something sensible and also to remind me to eat. I wasn't aware there was a web version actually!

@Jesstella also using Toggl! it really does need to leave us alone re: idle time, doesn't it? sometimes you just have to stare in despair at something for fifteen minutes, that's a vital part of the working process
not that I habitually work long hours every day, I work some very long days and some very short days and usually it averages out okay, or at least things tend to get done in reasonable timeframes 🤷

it's very cute that my work timer app sends me an alert if it's been running for over 8hrs to warn me that I might have forgotten to turn it off. 

unfortunately that is never usually the case. but I appreciate the reminder to at least consider stopping!

So please validate my life choices and vote for the big hot egg planet once more 💛 (hot egg image courtesy of NASA, ESA, and J. Olmsted (STScI)) https://t.co/rVrWIB1GmW

I also wrote two whole-ass papers on this planet! (Merritt et al. 2020, 2021). One where I couldn't find TiO and VO at high-res and one where I found 17 (!!!!) potential atomic signals instead. I spent 5yrs of my life on this planet and there's still SO MUCH MORE to discover. https://t.co/FMuOvTjmp6

Also, it's so close to its parent star that not only is it tidally distorted into an egg shape, its atmosphere is being blasted off into space, which is hardcore! Look at these huge iron and magnesium features in NUV! (Sing et al. 2019) https://t.co/pq5KYmAmRh

But! It looks like instead of TiO/VO, the stratosphere is being heated by atomic species instead? And it turns out there's loads of these?? Iron, chromium, vanadium, magnesium, calcium, scandium, potassium... here's some nice blobs from Hoeijmakers et al. 2020. https://t.co/LZhm1jsU6Z

It is the centre of a MYSTERY. It has a hot stratosphere driving these water emission features (Evans et al. 2017) and signs of potential heating molecules TiO and VO at low resolution, but these molecules are intriguingly absent at high-resolution! https://t.co/roDhiefJLh

If I am scribbling wildly I am listening. If I look like I am listening it's entirely possible I've accidentally tuned out and I'm actually thinking about the Roman occupation of Britain or something.

ADHD hack: when learning something or in a meeting or listening to a talk I take extensive notes I may never look at again because the point isn't the notes, the point is that making notes forces me to actually pay sustained attention.

(Doing nothing is also absolutely fine. The cult of productivity can get stuffed. It's that mindset that has me thinking I'm doing nothing when actually I'm just not getting paid for doing any of the things I do.)

I told my mum "at least when you die everyone will be devastated" and she nearly cried and then so did I, because it means we didn't become her.

So that's been weighing on me, and I want to put it down now. Done.

We took back all the love we had tried to give her and we cremated what was left and we buried the ashes and we left her behind.

The tragedy of that is sitting inside me. Of a woman who died utterly unmourned by those who should have wept for her loss.

My brother turned to me at her funeral with a furious little boy looking out of a man's eyes and said he'd never forgive her. At her funeral. As she burned. 

And we cried not for her but for the ghost of what she should have been to us and now never would be.

She raised us both, my mum and me, and we're both going to have to live with the scars and the unanswered questions forever. We'll never know why she did what she did to us. But I can't hate her any more, because when she died nobody who knew her mourned her. 

We were relieved.

Bonus tweet: special thanks to my PhD supervisor and all-round excellent human Neale Gibson. That I got this science done, this paper out, and my dang PhD finished, all under lockdown, is a credit to his supervision. 11/10

That's it! Big credit to my co-authors (@JDLothringer, @ExoSing, @nikolov_astro, @astrostevanus, @Sun_d_citizen and some losers without Twitter) and also thanks to @laura_mckemmish for her comments! Sorry about the dubious gif choices, happy to field questions. 10/10 https://t.co/pisZtM34j8

This sort of broad, relatively-simple atomic species search provides a really good jumping-off point for future, more in-depth work. It also highlights just how much there is to be found in ultra-hot Jupiters at optical wavelengths and how easy it is to find it! 9/10 https://t.co/lk70sJ5pD3

Our aim in publishing all 17 signals was in part to provide avenues for future research, but also to highlight the risks involved in the method. Most of the weak signals are probably noise, hence our set of 5 detection criteria. Don't believe everything over 3 sigma, folks. 8/10 https://t.co/AGiXImOCbn

Most of these detections back up the awesome previous work by Ben-Yami et al (2020), Hoeijmakers et al (2020), Cabot et al (2020) etc using HARPS or Borsa et al (2021) using ESPRESSO. The tentative Sc II detection is novel and points at a hot escaping atmosphere! 7/10 https://t.co/F1gMeHdsqe

After sorting by five criteria, we had 5 strong detections and 3 tentative ones, plus a bunch of weak signals which are probably mostly noise, but we published the lot, for reasons. First image is for Ca II. 6/10 https://t.co/SJWqR2z7Na

This allowed us to perform a huge and unlimited search for atomic species! We looked for everything up to yttrium, neutral and ionised. I thought we'd probably find three or four things. 

Imagine my surprise when 17 potential signals fell out of my automated pipeline.  5/10 https://t.co/K6fpuOSJGs

By adapting the analytical equation (Eq. 12) from Heng and Kitzmann (2017), we generated hundreds of atomic transmission spectra very quickly. These were found by Gibson et al (2020) to be pretty much identical to the fancier kind, given a few assumptions! 4/10 https://t.co/TPrX68eVXZ

Usually this is done by cross-correlating the residuals left after you remove the stellar/telluric spectrum with a model spectrum of the species you're looking for. These models are usually generated via numerical processes, which can be time-consuming. We did not do that. 3/10 https://t.co/r454gtescn

Doppler spectroscopy takes advantage of the Doppler shift of the exoplanetary atmosphere's (invisible) spectral lines to disentangle them from the dominant stellar spectrum and the telluric spectrum of the Earth's atmosphere. Here, have a diagram. 2/10 https://t.co/H3P6NCtDHK

My paper's up on arXiv! https://t.co/1V9JyS8p2H

Using just one UVES transit of WASP-121b, standard Doppler spectroscopy methodology, and template transmission spectra generated via an analytical equation, we detected 8 atomic species including a novel detection of Sc II! 1/10

I really need to read more productivity advice for ADHD folk because what works on neurotypical people is usually disastrous for me.

My brain cannot comprehend the concept of delayed gratification. It is focused on NOW. So what actually works is breaking down a task into tiny bits and visualising myself doing each task, then doing it, until something gets done.

So I can try to tell myself "after you clean the bathroom you can play Stardew Valley!" or something, but what will actually happen is that I'll sit on the bathroom floor on my phone for an hour instead, having zero actual fun and not getting anything done.

I've tried for years to follow the really common productivity advice of "reward yourself after you do something hard or boring" and I've just realised that this has never worked for me because I have ADHD and therefore my brain's reward system is totally broken.
